near---(nɪə)

Choose the appropriate stress pattern from the options. The syllables are written in capital letters.

association?

Choose the appropriate stress pattern from the options. The syllables are written in capital letters.

capitalism?
explanation:
A great number of words in English only have one syllable (for example go, eat, wait, eight, house, prince, friends, thieves, straight, etc.). In these cases the stress can only be located in that syllable. In longer words the stress can lie in any syllable:

Thus capitalism is stressed as: CAPitalism. it is stressed on the first syllable.

Choose the option that has a different stress on the first syllable.
Choose the option that has a different stress on the first syllable.
Choose the option that has a different stress pattern from the others.
Choose the option that has a different stress pattern from the others.
explanation:
Words ending with ''tion'' are stressed on the syllable before the ''tion''. Hence education would be stressed as;
e-du-CA-tion

Other options except education are nouns. Nouns and adjectives with two or more syllables will have their stress placed on the first syllable,

question:

question: There's a door at either end of the building?
explanation:
Either as used before the first of two given alternatives. When it is used as a determiner, it refers to both choices or possibilities
This means that there are two alternatives. At each end of the building, there is a door.

Either is used only when there are two persons or things. The statement can be interpreted as
''There are two ends in the building, and each of the ends has a door.
options: The building has two ends and two doors
The building has two ends, but only one door
The building has two ends, but I do not know which of the two has a door
The building has many ending each and for all

question: We have to iron out our difference at once?
options: We must clear up without delay our misunderstanding

We have to solve some of our problems for now
